p: Several studies have reported that improving oral hygiene care by either mechanical or chemical control of dental plaque biofilm formation can reduce the number of potential respiratory pathogens and consequently the risk and mortality risk of aspiration pneumonia by as much as 60% ( Dennesen et al., 2003; Tuon et al., 2017). Oral hygiene care, in these cases, include the use of mouthwash or gels, toothbrush, alone or in combination, together with sputum aspiration and saliva maintenance ( Hua et al., 2016). Specifically, the following practices should be taken: brushing of the teeth, gums, and tongue at least twice a day, moistening the oral mucosa and lips every 2–4 h, rinsing the mouth with mouthwash containing 0.5∼1.5% hydrogen peroxide, 0.05∼0.10% CPC or 0.23∼1% PV-I twice a day and wiping with 1.5% hydrogen peroxide.
